p:
The plain infection model without hygienic stress is given by
9.4
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ {x}_{n+1}=a{x}_n\left(1-{x}_n\right). $$\end{document}
x
n + 1
= a
x n

x n
.
where x
n denotes the relative number of infected being at time step n and “ a” is the infection rate. Utilizing the methods suggested in [ 2, 22, 38], the authors in [ 28] have modified the model ( 9.4) incorporating the hygienic stress and assuming a power law relation [ 44]. The modified model becomes a special case of the following model
9.5
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ {x}_{n+1}=a{x}_n\left(1-{x}_n\right)-{y}^a{a}^{\beta y}{x}_n\kern0.5em \ln \left(a{x}_n\right), $$\end{document}
x
n + 1
= a
x n
1 −
x n
−
y a
a βy
x n
ln
a
x n
,
in which y is a fixed positive number, α > 0, β > 0 are real positive parameters. The coefficient in front with a power of a, indicates that the hygienic stress of the virus increases with the infection rate, and this power is given by βy. Clearly when the stress coefficient vanishes, model ( 9.5) should reduce to the plain infection model ( 9.4). In order that the model ( 9.5) to reduce to ( 9.4) in the limiting case, that is, when the stress coefficient vanishes, the term y
α is introduced. The power law coefficient in front of the term x
n ln ( a x
n ) describes the equation of state for the transport coefficient.
